Introduction

To delve deeper into certain topics, science classes are divided into distinct disciplines:

AreaExamples
HumanPhilosophy, History, Literature, Geography
ExactPhysics, Mathematics, Chemistry
BiologicalZoology, Genetics, Biochemistry
Table 1: Example of sciences organized into different areas.

While History Tracers aligns with this approach, the manner in which subjects are taught can sometimes lead students to perceive the sciences as isolated entities, thus creating barriers to understanding.
We believe that the first step to removing these barriers is to recall our childhood, where natural curiosity allowed us to delve into new knowledge.

A contradiction

When we are children, we can't stop asking questions, which helps with our cognitive development (Chouinard, M. M., Harris, P. L., & Maratsos, M. P., ). However, as we grow, some people avoid asking questions and change their habits, seeking "solid" answers (truths), that are often overly simplistic. In doing so, they stop questioning and begin to accept information without inquiry. Recent studies suggest these "solid answers" are actually linked with a relativism that prevents them from being accepted as unquestionable truths (Cappelen, H., & Huvenes, T. T., ).

Another observation I have made is that people who seek simple answers are often the same ones who reject math, and consequently, reject logic. This is a contradiction because math is genuinely solid, as demonstrated by its proofs, although these are sometimes overlooked (Rocha, H., ).
So, how can we remove these barriers to math and science?

Reaching knowledge

To help readers overcome this obstacle, this section of the curriculum integrates the sciences. The methodology used considers several factors:

• There is no issue in acquiring more knowledge, because as Socrates said, "I neither know nor think that I know" ["I know that I know nothing"] (Plato, , pp. 15 ; Luiz Felipe Pondé, )
  • There are different types of intelligence (Şener, S., & Çokçalışkan, A., ), meaning that people understand content in various ways.

An example of the necessity of collaboration among the sciences can be observed in the genealogy of the Rodrigues family, who lived in Brazil during the 16th century. Different authors claimed that their [supposed] matriarch migrated from Europe, but genetic tests revealed she was Indigenous. One of the researchers failed to compare the dates he was writing with available documentation, resulting in a mother was more than two decades younger than her own daughter (History Tracers, , Rodrigues). This event shows how genetics, history, and mathematics can complement each other to correct historical descriptions.

Conclusion

Considering there are various issues in the learning process from the early years, which lead students to build barriers in different areas, this section of History Tracers begins by exploring how we started the action of counting. We will use the human body, our families, and small home experiments to demonstrate that science is not something to contradict; instead, it is a way to understand the world and acquire new knowledge.
